title: 9 Best Veronica Lake Movies , Ranked
body_text:
Veronica Lake was one of the hottest stars of the 1940s, known for her femme fatale roles in classic noirs films such as This Gun for Hire and The Blue Dahlia and her signature peek-a-boo hairstyle and glamorous presence, which made her a cinematic icon. Born in Brooklyn, New York, Lake and her family moved around a bit before settling in Beverly Hills, California in 1938, where she signed a brief contract with MGM Studios and studied at the Bliss-Hayden School of Acting. After appearing in various stage productions and extra roles in films, Lake earned her first major feature film role in the 1941 military drama, I Wanted Wings, which made her an overnight sensation.
Lake's star continued to rise as she starred in several hit classics, including Sullivan's Travels with Joel McCrea and a series of classic noir films starring opposite Alan Ladd, leading her to become one of the best stars of classic film noir. By the 1950s, Lake's bright star began to fade out as she became consumed by alcoholism, but despite her short-lived but marvelous career, Lake is immortalized in Hollywood history and remembered for her work in notable titles such as The Glass Key, Ramrod, and So Proudly We Hail!, which rank as some of the star's finest films.
9 'I Wanted Wings' (1941)
Directed by Mitchell Leisen
The military drama, I Wanted Wings, follows the professional and personal lives of three American men: a womanizer, Jeff Young (Ray Milland), a mechanic, Al Ludlow (William Holden), and a football star, Tom Cassidy (Wayne Morris), who, shortly before World War II, all become pilots for the U.S. Army Air Corps. As each of the men embarks on their journey into the military, they all endure their fair share of glory, shame, and tragedy which changes their lives forever.
Lake made her major film debut in I Wanted Wings, which ultimately launched her to infinite stardom and eventually to become one of the biggest female stars of the 1940s. I Wanted Wings earned overall praise for its authentic depiction of life in the military as well as its array of excellent performances by the leading male cast, but most critics noted Lake as the film's star attraction, which makes I Wanted Wings one of Lake's best and crucial films.

8 'Saigon' (1948)
Directed by Leslie Fenton
At the end of World War II, Major Larry Briggs (Alan Ladd) learns that his friend, Captain Mike Perry (Douglas Dick), only has two months to live as a result of a head injury and decides to show his friend a good time before he passes away. As the duo venture through Southeast Asia, they encounter suspicious law enforcement, a dangerous criminal and his beautiful secretary (Lake), who catches both of the men's hearts and affection.
The noir thriller, Saigon, was the fourth and final film Lake and Ladd made together, but compared to their other films, was not the most successful. While Lake and Ladd give exceptional performances, the plot of Saigon was cited as a bit silly and had noticeable unrealistic elements that proved it to be a less-than-exciting criminal noir. Despite its lack of positive reception, Lake and Ladd are the saving grace and have an undeniable chemistry that initially established them as a powerhouse couple of the silver screen.

7 'Ramrod' (1947)
Directed by André De Toth
Lake stars as the daughter of a wealthy rancher, Connie Dickason, who is under the control of a bullying cattle baron, Frank Ivey (Preston Foster), who had previously run Connie's husband out of town, leaving her to fend for herself and their property. When Connie hires a tough overseer, Dave Nash (Joel McCrea), Frank immediately retaliates, leading to an intense range war which ultimately reveals Connie's ruthless nature.
Ramrod is a tense Western directed by André De Toth, who was married to Lake at the time, and is easily one of Lake's most underrated films and performances. Even though Ramrod wasn't a major hit, it was a profitable production and still a worthy Lake film which reunites the actress with her Sullivan's Travels' co-star, McCrea, and also features her in a less glamorous role, proving that she was more than capable of taking on any roles outside her usual wheelhouse.

6 'So Proudly We Hail!' (1943)
Directed by Mark Sandrich
When a group of U.S. Army nurses ship out for a seemingly simple tour in Hawaii, the bombing of Pearl Harbor changes their course to Bataan in the Philippines, where they are overwhelmed with warfare and tending to wounded soldiers. Led by Lieutenant Janet Davidson (Claudette Colbert), Janet tries her best to keep her fellow nurses in high spirits, but when Bataan falls, the assault by Japanese troops takes just as an intense toll on the women, if not worse.
Lake stars alongside Claudette Colbert and Paulette Goddard in the war drama, So Proudly We Hail! which is based on the incredible true story of a group of American Red Cross nurses, known as the Angels of Bataan, who served in the Philippines during World War II. The film received immense praise for its uninhibited realism and brutal accuracy of the historical events, earning four Academy Award nominations. Lake and the overall cast deliver raw, emotionally-driven performances that are a fitting testament to the women they portrayed as well as the hardships and sacrifice they endured.

5 'The Glass Key' (1942)
Directed by Stuart Heisler
The Glass Key is a vital film noir which centers around a sketchy political boss, Paul Madvig (Brian Donlevy), who falls for Janet Henry (Lake), the daughter of a candidate for governor, and becomes determined to help her father win the election. Paul's right-hand-man, Ed Beaumont (Alan Ladd), doesn't believe Janet and her father are trustworthy, but his friend ignores him until he is suspected of killing Janet's brother. With no one else in Paul's corner, Ed sets out to not only clear his friend's name but also find the real killer.
Lake and Ladd reunite for the second time in the classic film noir, The Glass Key, which is based on the 1931 novel written by Dashiell Hammett. The movie is a thrilling murder mystery set against a cuthroat political backdrop and, today, is celebrated as a highly entertaining whodunit with a twist of big-city corruption that deserves more credit than it typically receives. Lake gives one of her all-time best performances, conveying the ideal femme fatale but with her own touch of coy seduction and mesmerizing allure, solidifying The Glass Key as one of Lake's top-tier films.

4 'I Married a Witch' (1942)
Directed by René Clair
Lake stars as a 17th century witch, Jennifer, who, right before she is burned at the stake, curses the family of her accuser, dooming every man in the family to marry the wrong woman. When Jennifer is freed centuries later, she decides to make the current relative of her accuser more miserable, Wallace Wooley (Fredric March), by giving him a love potion. As Wooley falls madly in love with Jennifer, the potion has some results that Jennifer wasn't expecting.
I Married a Witch is a classic romantic comedy based on the 1941 novel, The Passionate Witch, written by Thorne Smith. The film was a moderate success and was noted as an unusual but entertaining film, with the majority of critics raving over Lake, whose performance is considered by many today to be one of her most memorable. Lake delivers a delightfully dazzling performance, conveying her character with her signature sex appeal brilliantly blended with witty humor and a care-free tone that makes I Married a Witch a must-see Lake feature.

3 'The Blue Dahlia' (1946)
Directed by George Marshall
Alan Ladd stars as a United States Navy aviator, Johnny Morrison, who returns home and discovers his wife has been harboring secrets from him, leading to a heated and public argument between the couple. As Johnny leaves, he's picked up by a beautiful young woman, Joyce (Lake), who offers him a ride to a nearby motel. The next morning, Johnny hears a radio broadcast revealing that his wife has been found murdered and that he is the prime suspect.
The Blue Dahlia is a wicked classic film noir with an original screenplay by the infamous crime author, Raymond Chandler, as well as the third collaboration between Lake and Ladd. Chandler doesn't disappoint with this twisted murder mystery, demonstrating his mastery of the traditional whodunit combined with just enough romance and toughness. Lake and Ladd are as marvelous as ever, taking the lead as a pair of slightly star-crossed lovers who are brought together by unfortunate circumstances, only to bind them through misfortune and the will to survive the murderous mess.

2 'This Gun for Hire' (1942)
Directed by Frank Tuttle
This Gun for Hire is an iconic classic film noir starring Alan Ladd as a hired assassin, Philip Raven, who is paid for his recent job with marked bills, leading local authorities to try and track him down. As Philip tries to evade the police and take his revenge against his backstabbing client, he crosses paths with a mysterious woman, Ellen Graham (Lake), who, unbeknownst to Philip, is the fiancé of the lead detective trying to apprehend him.
This Gun for Hire reigns as one of Lake's greatest films of all time and marked a major milestone in both Lake and Ladd's careers, making them one of the biggest box office draws. The two have an undeniable and enthralling chemistry that is impossible to resist but Lake, in her own right, delivers an equally stunning individual performance as a femme fatale with a heart of gold, adding a new and appealing element to the traditional character archetype in the film noir genre.

1 'Sullivan's Travels' (1941)
Directed by Preston Sturges
Sullivan's Travels is one of the best films directed by Preston Sturges and tells the humorous story of a prominent movie director, John L. Sullivan (Joel McCrea), who is convinced that he can't film his masterpiece without experiencing a genuine amount of suffering and decides to disguise himself as a drifter. When his journey only leads him to a train ticket back to Hollywood and the company of a lovely woman (Lake), he doubles down on his efforts, which stirs up more trouble than the director initially intended.
Sullivan's Travels is considered to be Lake's breakthrough role that proved her potential as a promising leading lady and escalated her career to new heights of stardom. Lake captivates audiences with her hypnotic beauty and a superb and quick-witted performance, effortlessly holding their attention from beginning to end. Surprisingly, Sullivan's Travels wasn't an initial, even though it did earn several positive reviews from critics. Through the years, Sullivan's Travels has gained immense support and, today, is ranked as not only an essential classic comedy but also celebrated for Lake's performance, which is simply one for the ages.
